resources.string: Losing a pet is a traumatic experience for you, your family and your pet. The following are some tips for finding your lost pet.
Walk or drive through your neighbourhood as often as you can. Ask neighbors and anyone who works in the area. Have a picture and let people know to be on the lookout.
If your pet has a permanent ID, register the information in any local pet registries (SPCA database if available). Use any online resources available.
Place posters around the area your pet was lost. Use eye catching colors to help gain attention, make sure to include contact information.
Go to local animal shelters at least once a day, with a photo of your pet. Visiting is better than phoning as often shelter workers are very busy, and can\'t respond to phone calls.
Check with your local Animal Control.
If your pet was injured, it is possible it may have been taken to a local Animal Hospital or Vet.
Keep searching even if hope seems slim. Pets have been reunited with their guardians long after the have gone missing.
If your pet does not have a permanent form of ID, get one now before it is too late!

Being lost can be a very stressful event for both a pet and their guardians. If you have found an animal that you feel has been lost, trying to find the animal\'s home before the local SPCA or Animal Control is called. Most pets are found within the neighborhood where they are lost, and guardians are more than likely already searching for them.

If you must bring the animal to a local Animal Shelter, keep in mind that moving the animal from the neighbourhood reduces the chances that the pet will be reunited with his/her guardian. The shelter is a very traumatic experience for the animal, so if you are able, take some time to find the guardian on your own.

Is there a collar with a tag? If so, is there a phone number, or an address. Is there a municipal ID tag? A municipal tag can be used to locate the guardian through the local animal control office or SPCA.

If the animal you found has an ear tattoo, it is possible that it could be used to help track down the guardian of the animal. Check with your local veterinary office to see if it is possible. Some animals may have tattoos on other areas of their body, such as their abdomen or inside leg. These are breeder tattoos and usually can only be traced to the original breeder.
Many pets have microchips, but the only way to know for sure is to take the animal to a local veterinary clinic, Animal Control service or SPCA shelter.

Use the internet. There are many sites dedicated to helping reunite lost pets with with their guardians. Put up found pet posters with a description and talk to people in the neighbourhood. Contact your local SPCA shelter or Animal Control to report the animal and let them know if you are willing to hold the animal until the guardian is located.

Contact local veterinary clinics, many of them keep lost and found records. Check the local classifieds. Don\'t forget, if the guardian is located, please remember to contact groups you have previously contacted to update them.
